key_insight: Introducing a nested (hierarchical) learning scheme that lets agents learn coarse-to-fine browser strategies — enabling reliable, efficient full-browser interactions by splitting high-level planning from low-level page manipulation and summarization.
problem_solved: Bridges the gap between API/URL-limited information retrieval and messy, verbose real-browser interactions: it reduces complexity from fine-grained control and verbose page returns so agentic search can access richer web content.
method: Nested/hierarchical policy learning: a high-level planner issues goals and a low-level browser controller executes fine-grained DOM actions and scraping.
Page-content compression & on-the-fly summarization: digest verbose HTML/text into task-relevant chunks for the planner to avoid token/decision overload.
Training with simulated/browser-in-the-loop episodes and curriculum-style tasks to learn robust action abstractions and recovery behaviors for noisy web environments.
impact: Enables practical, scalable agentic browsing for complex information-seeking tasks, improving agent autonomy and retrieval fidelity while reducing token/interaction overhead — useful for building more capable web agents, research assistants, and autonomous data collectors.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: high-level planner → nested low-level browser controller → summarizer → feedback loop
Before/after comparison: URL/API-only retrieval vs nested full-browser interaction (coverage, tokens, success rate)
Sequence visualization: example episode showing planner goal, DOM actions, page summary, planner update
Bar chart or table: metrics (task success, actions per task, token usage) comparing baseline ReAct-style agents and the nested approach
paper_title: Nested Browser-Use Learning for Agentic Information Seeking
paper_authors: Baixuan Li, Jialong Wu, Wenbiao Yin, Kuan Li, Zhongwang Zhang
